unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Appropriate Test Type
question_text:
Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program.
The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math.
The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below:
When performing a chi-squared test for goodness of fit, suppose strong evidence exists that students in the program have math grades different than everybody else does.
What kind of test would one use to prove the claim that the course actually improves math grades?

solution:
Remember, a chi-squared goodness of fit test gives only two-sided results.

To attempt to show the program helps, one could do a one-proportion $Z$-test on the proportion of those in the program with A's compared to everybody else. Additional one-proportion $Z$-tests can be performed with the rest of the grades (B's, C's, and so on).

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; when dealing with two proportions, a two-proportion test may be appropriate. However, this table deals with several proportions on a single variable.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a linear regression $T$-test is suited for quantitative data, not the categorical data in this table.

Choice 'D' and 'E' and both incorrect; ANY chi-squared test is two-sided and will not test for improvement.
